Definition: Classify the given comment into threat and non-threat. Threat means someone will be hurt or harmed.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: He should be executed, not given 48 years.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment conveys a violent threat to someone.

Comment: If you think putting Alaska Natives in charge of ANY natural resource will provide any degree of protection or conservation, you apparently do not read much. Check out the history of the Kilbuck caribou herd. Or, if you really want an education, go to Bethel in May and June when the Kuskokwim delta is filled with ducks and geese tending their nests. You can watch fifteen or twenty boats go out there every morning and spend the day killing ducks and geese even though it is totally illegal and unethical, until their boats are literally full, then coming back to town, taking a dozen or two home for supper, coming back the next day, dumping the other hundred or so dead birds out of the boat and going back out to blast a couple hundred more. Yep, they are definitely "Stewards of the Land" alright. Or go do a census of game within 30 miles of ANY village in NW or SW Alaska. No moose, no caribou. If it moves, kill it. If it flies it dies.

Most Catholics don't even know what the Curia is, much less know who is in that institution or group; but you want it dismantled. Comment: There may be. The annulment process requires getting the other spouse to complete their part of the process. This situation is ripe for the abused party to be victimized again by someone who is vindictive or demanding something (like giving up child support in exchange for cooperation). 

It's rare that someone marries a known abuser. The marriage may have been entered with the best preparation and good intentions, but if drugs, alcohol, trauma, or mental illness enter the picture, the marriage may be doomed and, in some cases, dangerous. 

The system may work well with two well-adjusted, communicating individuals who agree on an annulment, but that is very often not the case. In my professional capacity, I had to write the tribunal twice on behalf of a client who married someone who later developed paranoid schizophrenia to inform them that contacting the spouse could be dangerous to my client and destabilizing to the spouse. It took several appeals to get them to understand.

Comment: Know Your Rights

I.         Ask to be taken to an immigration judge. Be aware the officer will try to get you to sign a Voluntary Departure Agreement. You do not have to do so.
 
 

2.       Answer no questions other than your name.
 
 

3.         Ask to speak to the Mexican Consulate.
 
 

4.       Ask the officer to set a bond in your case.
 
 

5.         When you see the judge (assuming you have not been previously deported), you may be able to avoid or delay deportation if:
 
 

a.         You have been in the United States for more than IO years and you have certain family members that are legally in the United States.
 
 

b.       You have been the victim of a crime in the United States.
 
 

c.         You have a fear of persecution if returned to your country.
 
 

d.         You are the beneficiary of a family-based immigration petition.

To be continued

Comment: Why are so many of the refugees who are apparently safe in places like Lebanon, Turkey, Jordan and Kenya clamouring to get to the West? The main reasons, of course, are economic, which supports the point made in my original comment. As for the biblical analogy, Joseph and Mary travelled to Bethlehem to participate in a census. Subsequently, the bible holds that they fled to Egypt to escape King Herod's purge of newborn males, although later, after Herod died and the risk diminished, returned to Judah. They didn't seek permanent refuge in Egypt and thus don't provide an analogy to those who today seek to get to the West. In any case, many view the biblical stories as a series of parables, akin to moral lessons rather than actual history, while some see the bible as essentially heavily edited propaganda that was intended to suit the political interests of the early Christian church and its leaders. Today, it's mainly fundamentalists who promote literalist interpretations of the bible.

Comment: BBC is a known propaganda station. If the BBC convinced you that a Russian missile hit MH-17, then you've been misled by disinformation. There has been no solid evidence presented of this, and most of the best evidence on the matter suggests that MH-17 was hit with a missile from West Ukraine's territory. The "Russian missile system" that is suspected to have hit the plane is possessed by the West Ukrainian military, as well as others in the region.
The Dutch investigation of MH-17 is only one of competing investigations, and is not an impartial investigation, but is a private and partisan investigation, which was created after the rejection of a call for creation of a non-partisan investigation team. The Dutch investigation team includes the West Ukrainian government, and has not accepted radar data submitted by Russia, or other evidence submitted - and has also not released any evidence of its own to back up any of its claims.
It is therefore impossible that BBC proved anything.

Comment: About 20 years ago, I landed at LAX, rented a car and drove out of the lot trying to find the entrance to 105.  I was visiting a cousin living in Temple City.

I took some wrong turns and was on Century Blvd, going east, into Inglewood.  After about 2-3 miles, the neighborhood began to look rundown, graffiti on buldings, etc.  I got worried and did a U-turn.  Then at about the third intersection going back, I got the red light, and was in the left lane behind another car.  

In the right lane, a car at the line was approached by two young men, who started washing the windshield and showed a placard, "window wash $10".  Then one of the men knocked at the driver's window with his hand out.  I guess the driver ignored him, and the young guy hit the window with the butt of his squeegee.

At that moment, I was praying for an LAPD cruiser to drive by.  But to my relief, the light turned green, and the car in front hit the gas and took off.  I wasn't far behind.

Comment: "Video visitation" provides a safe and secure form of communication between the inmate and family/friends they are communicating with. 
-
Some jails have "video phones" either in or adjacent to their housing dayrooms which negates moving inmates in and out of housing units to other locations for a visit. That cuts down on staffing requirements to both move and monitor the movement of dozens to potentially hundreds of inmates (for larger jails) being moved around the jail solely to accomplish "traditional visiting" in a "visitation area." 
-
In older jails, inmates were moved almost constantly from their housing cells to recreation yards and to visitation booths/areas.....not all at once, but in a virtual constant flow of movement that required staffing to conduct the movements in a safe and orderly manner.
-
In newer jails, the rec yards and video phones are placed in or adjacent to each of the housing areas, which saves time, resources, and money to accomplish the same thing.

Comment: "The only conclusion to reach is that incomes are not being reported, says Mr. Wozny. A segment of the population is effectively subsidizing a group that refuses to pay its taxes." That is true to an extent but it is also the case that house price inflation has superseded the incomes of those that originally purchased a once affordable house. Case in point: A family purchases their house in Kerrisdale in 1970 for around $45, 000. They could sell it today for around $5m (a tear down no less). Their income has never been crazy and they worked hard to afford what was then a moderately expensive house and live in what is now a stratospherically expensive house. But their income tax report would be wildly out of line with the value of the house - they could never afford the same thing today. So, by all means nail people who are scamming the system, but there are many who have simply benefited by going about their business and using their house as it was meant to be used: as a home.

Comment: C'mon now Neil--not failing? What do you call it then? Our 4th graders are an average two school years behind the NAEP reading test scores of 4th graders in states spending half of what we do. Two school years behind at age 10. Is there a more task for a school system than early childhood literacy? 

You can't write-off our crisis of early childhood literacy just because of our rural schools. According to GlobalReportCard.org, ASD is only slightly above average in outcomes in a state that is 47th in overall NAEP scores. There are 22 Alaska school districts (mostly rural) that score higher than ASD. Skagway was actually #1 student outcomes while having  the highest unemployment rate in the state. 

The system does have some successes. My kids did pretty well in the ASD. My daughter got accepted to Ivy League schools with an ASD education. Out of 46,000 kids there are always going to be success stories in-spite of the low quality overall.

Comment: The allegation that the pastor is a "priest, who is 'on loan' from another diocese evidently because he had a turbulent history there" is a scurrilous slur with no foundation at all.

I made some inquiries in the Diocese of Knoxville through Fr. John R. Dowling, the pastor at Holy Ghost Catholic Church, and found that Fr. Christopher Riehl, a late vocation, was ordained in Knoxville in 2009. As with a number of priests in that diocese he is trained in both the current and 1962 Missals.

After going through some training in various venues in the diocese he was assigned to St. Mary’s Church in Johnson City to a bi-weekly Mass using the 1962 Missal in response to 25 years of requests by the Five Rivers Deanery.

This was in addition to his serving as associate at St John Neumann parish in the Knoxville suburb of Farragut.

In 2014, where the article begins, he was incardinated with Bishop Stika’s permission in the Diocese of Charlotte, which is still short of priests.

Comment: Totally different scenario.  With a TFSA, you put after-tax dollars into savings, but don't pay tax on the interest.  With an RHOSP, you pay into the RHOSP and get the interest on the investment, and get a refund for the income tax you paid on the money you put into the RHOSP.  I saved my first down payment using the RHOSP, and getting a nice fat refund cheque after filing my taxes was a great incentive, because I used that money for things I really wanted. (In today's world, that could have been put into a TFSA, which would mean a double tax savings)

Comment: One of the most fundamental principles of a free and democratic society is that those who wield power must, themselves, be subjected to rules and oversight. Right up to parliament and the president being subject to the rule of law.

The same goes for teachers. If teachers do not obey the rules, laws and regulations that their superiors pass over them - then they lose all moral and legitimate authority to enforce rules over pupils.
This is a settled matter - the minister of education banned hair rules more than 15 years ago on the grounds that they intrude excessively on constitutional rights (including freedom of religion and freedom of expression) with no discernible reason or benefit for doing so.

The lack of enforcement is not an excuse for violating the rules and if the department of education will not enforce the rules, then it's up to the pupils to demand their rights themselves.

Of course it's not ideal to have strikes. But the onus on preventing this one was on the school.

Comment: I've spent the last two decades of my life in the military and truly have no problem with these folks sitting for the anthem.  As Elway said, each and every one of them have the Constitutional right to do so.  There's nothing anti-American about sitting during the anthem, there's nothing racist about sitting, and there's certainly nothing illegal about it.  That's not to say I agree with the reasoning behind it, I don't.  I think Kaepernick is a spoiled, ignorant, kid with little to no understanding of the true nature and facts of what he believes he's protesting.  That said, he has every right to do it, and as a career military man I support that right even though I don't support the cause.  I haven't spent the last twenty years defending the Constitution for nothing.  You don't have to agree with the cause but accept that they have the right just as the Charlottesville protesters do.

Twas the right before Christmas, when all through the states, 'Thug legislatures were ginning up hate. In Raleigh they turned out the new Democrat's lights, While Columbus went after women's health care rights.

Comment: It is great to see that DM has reinstated the comments, for without them, the contents of the articles are often (mostly) one-dimensional opinions of the author. To me, what adds depth and dimension to any article are the comments from the readers,  whether they agree or disagree, often provide a different dimension to the issues under discussion. Depending on the topic of conversation, one can often interpret the psyche of the respondents and extrapolate that into the underlying feelings that run deep within general population.
Trolls of the past will eventually return, but most are easy to  identify and ignore. The platform should allow for diverse and even extreme views to be expressed, for it is only once these views are brought into the open, can these views be questioned, challenged and potentially changed. People with views diametrically opposed to our own are still part of society, and whether we like it or not, are still able to influence others in many different ways.

Comment: The engine of capitalism (or for that matter any free enterprise system) is Adam Smith's  observation of the "Invisible  Hand ".Indeed it seems it is the engine of political democracy as well. The Invisible Hand is by definition not a monolith but the result of innumerable human components each seeking its "own best interest" which results in a position/conclusion as to what is in the best interest of the majority.  Clearly this recognizes there is a minority but that minority is also made up of various different interests , none of which carried the day or has a consensus.

If you want to effectively pursue the goals of "social justice" the concept of the Invisible Hand requires that you work to achieve those goals at the individual level. Promoting top down government control is a grand approach when it is only the granular/individual level  that actually effects real change. Change the hearts and minds of the individual and you will get the effective change you desire in Capitalism.

Comment: Thank you, Lamont.

But actually,  my parents are Jewish Poles who were able to come out of hiding only after the Soviet Army pushed back the Nazis.  

In the immediate post war period, there were soldiers billeted in their home who protected them from some post war murders of jews committed by the local townspeople.   As well, the soldiers were able to secure some items that had been stolen from their home by neighbours while my parents were in hiding. After loosing both of their families, including their daughter, my parents were very grateful for these acts of kindness.

The story related to me by my mother was that the billeted soldiers used to drink and sing well into the night, which is how these folk songs became a part of my childhood.

In return, as my mother lay dying, I sang Kalinka to her.

And that's why today I feel as though a large part of my childhood died.

Comment: The conservative economist Walter Williams said, correctly, that the introduction of the minimum wage under FDR in 1938 had the effect of kicking a lot of black workers out of their jobs. He did not say why, he just said: Therefore, minimum wage is a bad idea.

The reason so many African-Americans lost their jobs, especially in the South, was that there was a two-tiered wage system for many jobs, with blacks typically getting paid half what whites were. Since everyone now had to be paid the same, white employers fired their black workers and hired whites in their places. Williams neglected to point out that the actual reason for the blacks losing their jobs was racism, not the minimum wage.

RD is reminding us of the truth of John Kenneth Galbraith's "The modern conservative is engaged in one of man's oldest exercises in moral philosophy; that is, the search for a superior moral justification for selfishness". RD doesn't want to pay more for a Big Mac.

Comment: "If 'neither law nor conscience stops a determined killer' then why bother with either?"

I won't speak to conscience aspect in this context, but the law serves two purposes.  First, it codifies societies standards of behavior and establishes the punishments for failing to follow those standards, hopefully acting as a deterrent to criminal behavior.  This is the aspect Kafer is alluding to.  The other purpose is to provide a basis for prosecuting and punishing those who aren't deterred, Kafer's "determined killer."  We bother with the law because even if the deterrent value of the law fails, we still need the prosecutorial foundation.

Comment: Sorry, Bob, I cannot agree this firing is a "constitutional crisis" simply because of its timing during ongoing FBI investigations of possible ties between the Trump campaign and the Russians.

I am glad you agree the president has the authority to hire and fire any of his appointees at any time for any reason.

But a constitutional crisis is normally a situation where a branch acts outside its constitutional authority and/or infringes on the constitutional authority of another branch or when 2 of the 3 (or all 3 ) branches are at such loggerheads that the nation's business cannot be done.  (Congress cutting off funding of the executive and thus shutting down the government would be an example.)

As in all large, complex public bureaucracies, the director does not lead or conduct investigations.  And the bureau's current investigations will continue regardless of who the director is.  

If Trump interferes with investigations, the constitutional crisis threshold may be reached.

Comment: Puuloa, from Office of Elections:

RESIGNATION REQUIREMENTS
If a candidate is a state or county officeholder seeking a federal office, there is no resignation requirement.

Additionally, a state or county officeholder whose successor would regularly be elected at the same election in which they are a candidate for another state or county office is not required to resign.

However, a state or county officeholder, whose successor would not regularly be elected at the same election in which they are a candidate for another state or county office is required to resign. This resignation needs to occur prior to the state or county officeholder filing a nomination paper for the new state or county office.

http://elections.hawaii.gov/candidates/candidate-filing/

Comment: Your suggestion that the particular order and speed of things is the "only" Christian response is very restricting. People need to have the flexibility to take the next good--or Christian--step, then the one after that, then the one after that. I agree with the goal, but not the assumption of knowing the best, or most effective, way to get there. Francis doesn't see himself as a "dictator" type, and seems most concerned with getting the Body of Christ to come back to life and fulfill its promise as a more decentralized Body than with other issues. Comment: What Ted Rubin stated about immediate annuities is simply not true.  There is a cash with refund option if the annuitant dies early on, any unpaid amount goes to the named beneficiary.

In fact, most economists who study retirement trends share this view, while sadly and ironically most so called financial advisors are oppossed to them (probably because they want to keep the clients' money in mutual funds generating fees as to be agreeable in front of a brain washed public trained to hate guaranteed incone annuities).

I urge everyone to read the book Paychecks and Playchecks by Tom Henga.  Anyone without an income annuity as part of their retirement portfolio will have a scientifically subpar retirement.  Period.  Lastly see an insurance agent, who is also registered to offer invrstments about retirement, not a financial advisor.

Comment: Yes, public transportation services Like Uber and Lift, now subject to the City's regulatory code, should be held to the same standards that every other public transportation provider is held to.  

Taxis have an unfunded mandate from the City requiring them to have wheelchair accessible vehicles in at least 10% of their fleet.  They can only charge the same rates as regular cabs.  This results in the taxi companies subsidizing them, while at the same time trying to remain competitive with a huge multi-national corporation that does not share that mandate.

While this denial of service to wheelchair-bound users is probably the most egregious of Novick's concessions to Uber (although I would argue that a close second is surely the Non-Disclosure Agreement they signed) there are many others, such as requiring smart phones and credit cards.   This disproportionately affects the elderly and low-income.  Too bad they don't have lobbyists, Uber has 10.

Comment: I try and I try...and I can't, for the life of me, figure out why 28 parties is a bad thing! How is having a wealth of choice in who to vote for worse than the hearing the common complaint ending in "none of the above"?!

I would *love* to be able to vote for somebody or some party that more closely represents my concerns and interests. Then, if necessary, when they go to Ottawa they make any needed compromise in order to work toward their stated goals.

The system we have now involves my compromising right at the start. I have to figure out who I dislike least of the 3 big parties. That person then (if I'm lucky) goes to Ottawa to implement an agenda that I sometimes have very little agreement with. 

Ultimately, the composition of parliament should reflect the will of the people. It should not reward or penalize voters with skewed numbers in parliament due to a quirk in the system.

Comment: Commissioner Bailey and some of the commenters here seem to have little idea of the structural engineering that goes into rooftop greenhouses. I've been involved in building three large greenhouse spaces 32,000 sf or bigger on roofs in Montreal (which has a larger annual snowfall than Anchorage), I understand the issues. They are far from "flimsy" and are carefully engineered to manage snow load, wind shear, seismic shift, etc. 

The benefits of such greenhouses are substantial. They are very efficient farms and produce, on average, 10-15 times more produce per square foot than soil-based farming and while they can provide high-quality vegetable produce all year around, they also provide substantial energy savings to the building below during both winter and summer.

For more informed perspective about rooftop agriculture, the commission and commenters might do well to consult www.lufa.com/en/our-farms.html. We'd be pleased to provide fact-based information.

Kurt D. Lynn - Co-founder

Comment: Eric, I'm sad to hear about your difficult time in the military, as I had a very good experience  in my draftee army  era  of 1958-61. Basic training in this recently integrated army was especially interesting as we got to know guys from about every possible background.
As far as speaking my mind, I've never found it difficult to do so  and this was true in the army, including my USASA service in our isolated  little post in Lubeck  northern Germany.  One time, in fact, in 1961  I was able to share my views on Viet Nam--  Our chaplain from our main base was scheduled to come give us a lecture on "Why the US military should be in S.E. Asia." However, he couldn't make it up to Lubeck so just mailed us the informational material.  Well, our captain knew I liked to talk so he gave me the info and told me to do the lecture.  Having studied SE Asia earlier, I instead titled my talk as "Why we should not be in S.E. Asia."  Result?     I  finally got my promotion to Spec 5.

Seems to me they were little better off than when this started.  This plan could not work forever and it looks a lot like it is starting to collapse.  Those who complain about the republican plan might want to remember the Pelosi quote, when asked about what was in the ACA bill..

Comment: No, technically, the LG has to ask the person with the most seats to form the government.  Then, that Premier can either accept or decline.  Accept means facing the house in a confidence motion.  Decline means the LG asks the party with the next most seats. When there is a non-confidence vote and the goverment loses, the LG can ask the second to form the government or call another election.  Federally, Harper forestalled this by proroguing parliament, but that bridge has been burned.
The invitation to form government has to come from the LG as titular head of government.

Comment: After living with me for a couple of weeks, one evening one of them said, "I think I should tell you something."

"What?"

"I did time."

"Where?"

"State pen."

"What for?"

"First degree murder."

"You're out now.  Tell me about it."

"I was at East High School and wouldn't join the gang.  Got word thru the grape vine that there was a hit out on me ... by the gang leader.  I got a rifle, hid in the bushes, and ambushed him when he came for me, then turned myself in.  Got a 10 year sentence.  Was released after three.  The guy I shot had a felony record a mile long, and I'd never been in any trouble before that."

Good guy, and he was working to turn his life around.  But most people wouldn't have hired him.  I understood that he did what he had to do to survive.  I'd hired him based on my impression of his positive attitude and character.  Didn't feel I needed a background check.

Comment: The elimination of flow through shares will result in less taxation because now less new fields will be found. Therefore less economic activity will occur meaning less taxes and no royalty income from these new discoveries. What flow through shares do is allow producers to raise capital to drill these speculative wells. The well gets drilled and if it is successful adjacent wells are now developmental.  A new mini multiplier effect is created with taxation occurring on all the activity in the form of GST, payroll taxes, service company taxes etc not to mention royalty payments.  The flow through share in the hands of the investor allows that investor to deduct the amount from their annual revenue. The investor gets  tax relief however the investor provides the capital that allows the small producer to take the chance on this risky and often unsuccessful target. What will happen now? These wells won't get drilled.  There will be no tax savings but a net loss.

"Voters in Broomfield on Tuesday approved by a 57 percent margin giving their government more authority over the industry."

"Voters in Broomfield on Tuesday approved Question 301 by a 15 percent margin, giving their government more authority over the industry."
=====

Comment: And unfortunately my sales tax (or alternatively money for schools, maintenance, hospitals, etc. under Caldara's "Fix Our Roads" initiative) already goes to wider roads.

Your point is apt though, there are a lot of new places that are difficult to live without a car. That's a planning problem. And not one Caldara seems inclined to fix. 

Widening roads to ease congestions is asinine; increased capacity invariably leads to increased congestion. You and I agree on a lot, but we disagree on what to do about it. I have already seen places I grew up paved over to increase capacity. We can turn into another California: suburbia as far as the eye can see, a million highways with bumper to bumper traffic, and we can lose everything that we love about it. Or we can choose to do something different. 

I love Denver and all of Colorado and don't want to move, so I'm trying to do all I can to make sure what makes Colorado great isn't sacrificed in the name of "road capacity" (=wider roads).

Comment: I guess this issue must be above the pay grade of some frustrated... commenters.  I never once said that a debt cannot be sold.  (Show me where I did).  Let's erase the chalkboard and go back to square one.  Consumers were yelling and screaming about mistreatment by debt collectors in the 1970s.  Phone calls at all hours of the night.  Repeated calls to employers, neighbors, friends, relatives.  The tone of voice, language used by collectors were over the top.  In 1977, in response to the demands of consumers, the Congress passed the law.  The issue I am addressing is the collector of the debt, not the debt itself.  I am saying that it does not matter if the debt is sold five times, if the collector is abusive, then the law has been violated.  What the Court is doing here is given shelter and comfort to businesses buying debt instruments, thus avoiding the intent of the law itself.  Get it?  Got it?  Good.

Comment: I've explored my feelings on the rail in the past with my Yesterday's Tomorrow cartoons, where I compared the similarities between the rail and the H3 relative to public opinion on both projects at their respective times. I wasn't for rail, but surely I will benefit from it if and when it is completed, along with the next generation of youth who will ride it absolved from the burdens that the current generation has to deal with.

That being said, we face a heavy burden, one that to many does not justify the projected effect the rail would have on alleviating traffic (it simply would not do enough for its cost.)

I wasn't for rail when it was proposed, but now that part of it has been built, I wouldn't consider myself anti-rail. I consider myself anti-how this project has been handled. We might as well make the most of the situation at hand. I'll ride it if it gets built, but if it doesn't, it'd be nice to have a park.

Comment: When computers for the home came available, all of us were fascinated. Both my son and two daughters used it routinely. All three had the ongoing benefit of a computer throughout their secondary and post secondary education. They viewed them as tools for education as well as a means of entertainment. All of them are now much more computer literate than their parents and all continue to make use of computers in their daily routines. None of them, however, had any desire to become programmers or to study computer science. All were admitted to university and all benefited from their computer literacy. I would hazard to guess that a great many households shared this experience with computers. All got a 'head start' but my son did not get a 'big advantage. We had friends and acquaintances whose sons and daughters did enter the 'tech' world but certainly there were more sons than daughters choosing the field. None that we knew were ever discouraged from entering it because of their gender.

Comment: THINK GLOBALLY AND ACT LOCALLY

It's hard to argue with Chip and Larry's criticism of Trump's cuts to the Federal science budget, but what about our State Government? Why are they silent on the lack of environmental leadership by Hawaii's legislators?

This session, bills to establish local carbon-offset certification for Haleakala reforestation stalled, and a bill to update the state's energy plan to include ground transportation and aviation  (our #1 source of climate pollution), didn't even get a hearing. Multiple measures to increase the state's paltry petroleum fuel tax were also rejected.

We do need research, but we need actions on CO2 even more. 

Come on guys, shouldn't concerned citizens apply pressure at both the Federal and State levels of government to reduce climate pollution and to mitigate the effects of climate change?

Did God intrinsically (ontologicaly) alter Mary at her conception?

This is getting close to predestination to me and even closer to the dehumanization of Mary that distances her from being my mother. It is a sweeter and more palatable sterilization of Mary by associating only Mary's mom with the aches, pains and transformations of pregnancy.
If Mary was "ontologically" elevated at conception - woman priest? Birth Jesus - Eucharist? Immplication....?

Comment: What I really don't understand about the rational behind making gun control one of the major platforms for half of the country is that it is not the best use of the limited resource that is our national attention span.  

I don't disagree that the country needs to find a way to curb violent homicides, assaults and accidental death, but taking away guns isn't where we can do the most good - not even slightly.

Guns were involved in 1.3% of all deaths in 2013 - that included 11,208 by homicide, 21,175 by suicide and 505 in cases like this, accidental shootings.  

100% of the deaths by suicide could potentially have been prevented by better mental health care and probably 75-80% of the homicides could have been prevented if the perpetrators had better economic opportunities.

Meanwhile heart disease took 611,105 people, cancer 584,881, respiratory diseases 149,205, mechanical accidents and drowning  130,052, and strokes killed 128,978. Being unhealthy, stupid and smoking are the issues.

Comment: Biblical prophecy certainly is interesting in connection with what we are seeing. Much of it is incomprehensible to me, but the parts about the earth are easy to understand and are scary right-on.  Some of the best is actually from the old testament, and I quoted some of it recently. Hosea says that there will be mass die-offs, including beasts of the field, the birds in the sky, and even the fishes of the sea will die. Daniel has a fascinating prophecy that says that knowledge will increase, and the people will be highly mobile. Certainly that is the case of our era, something that began not that long ago and is in stark contrast to the rest of human history. The trees will burn, the oceans will die, and people will be terrified of the storms. There will be stark increases in earthquakes and war.   

I came to my conclusions through science that the earth has been dealt a fatal blow, but when I read biblical prophecy I thought my hair would catch fire, it was so uncanny.

Comment: Ten or twelve years ago when the Knowles Administration was VERY reluctantly trying to implement the Clinton Era Welfare to Work reforms forced on Clinton and the Democrats by Newt Gingrich, we were trying to figure out how to do this in a rigid merit system and under union contracts; no easy task.   Very few of our potential Welfare to Work applicants could even meet the minimum qualifications for entry-level jobs, Range 8 or 10.   At that time, a single woman with two dependent children if she availed herself of all of the economic benefits for which she was eligible had an income roughly equivalent to a Range 14 or so, and she'd have more disposable income.   That's a job for which she would never qualify absent ten years of so of successful experience.   She would be crazy to go to work for us, few did, and fewer stayed long; they were and still are doing better staying home in their bathrobe - knew one, real well.

Comment: Peter; there are agricultural jobs where American workers predominate, the wheat harvest in the mid west and Canada for example. Cost to the processer is much more than wages, add in transportation, food , housing it all adds up but that's the cost, cutting corners on food, housing using old broken down equipment is just not viable. Doing business like the 1950'sdoesn't work anywhere else why would it work in fish processing, look at the difference in boats in BB, wooden sails to Al 32 ft tugs.

Comment: Cat:

Some facts: 

Fact #1: Canadian bond yields bottomed in February 2016. The five -year Canada was at 0.40% then and the yield now has almost tripled, currently it is at 1.10% as of Jan. 09, 2017.

Fact #2: At the same time (February 2016), Enbridge common shares traded at $43.00 per share. Today these same shares trade for $57.50 on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Have a look.

Fact #3: While bond yields have risen significantly over the last 11 months, Enbridge common shares have risen in price by approximately 34%. Add in dividends and you'd be a bit north of 37% for total return.

Fact #4:  Since interest rates have bottomed and risen considerably, Enbridge common shares (symbol: ENB) have also risen considerably.  

No theories. No opinions. Simple, obvious facts available to anyone who cares to spend a few minutes of their time to take even a cursory look into what has really taken place and not what they think should have happened or hope will happen.   

SFI

Comment: The problem with community papers is that they cover all the local and important (but not world-shattering) items that are actual of impact to your life: Municipal politics, local crime, local events.  These are all things that may directly impact your life.  They are also not as sexy as what gets reported in the "big media".  Famine in South Sudan is a big deal, but has little or no direct impact on your life here and there is little you can do about it.  With the internet, you would think the local news would flourish while the Google's of the world kill the big media.  Sadly, both local and national media is getting killed, local even faster as people refuse to read "paper".  I am as guilty as anyone else of "amusing myself to death" with international news of little direct impact.  How do we fix this?  We need those local reporters and media outlets.

Comment: All Canadians had the chance to either attend a town hall or submit their perspectives online to the government on this issue. The vast majority of experts at the hearings and a clear majority of the public at town halls supported a form of proportional representation. The Trudeau government promised that 2015 would be the last under FPTP and that 'all votes would count' next election. Yet, we now have Liberals, on the committee, saying the changes are too rushed and radical despite the fact that they took about 9 months to get the process underway. Neither the Greens nor the NDP support a referendum, so the fact that a referendum is being recommended from the committe suggests that the 5 Liberals on the committe wouldn't support what a clear majority had suggested. I suspect Mr. Trudeau gave them their marching orders after it became clear that proportional representation would be the result, a system which would improve democracy but stop 39% popular vote majorities.

Comment: The spin put on the entire SB21 debacle was that it would create jobs and fill the pipeline with oil, while voting against it would cause the oil companies to flee. Comment: Tribal sovereignty wasn't given up, land rights were. I wasn't trying to be inflammatory in regards to who's been here longer, only trying to state facts. I also think that resource development can be done responsibly.
In regards to forced sterilizations, the studies I've found were only done in a handful of areas and found that between 25 and 50% of Native American women were either sterilized without consent or were given misleading or incorrect information about the procedure. This started in the 60s and continued until IHS introduced new regulations in the 70s. It could be that none of the affected were Alaska Natives, but I think that's unlikely.
You asked "When are we going to stop feeling guilty?" so I assumed you were talking about the U.S. in general, not you individually. I don't think you personally should feel guilty.

Comment: You makes it sound like a 401K is a bad thing. If you're working for a company that doesn't invest it well, that's true, but the State of Alaska does a good job of investing the Tier 4 retirement funds and they grow at a good pace. Sure, compared to Tier 1, the Tier 4 worker has to put a lot more of their own money in, but we're legally assured the money will actually be there, whereas the Tier 1 system was never fully funded, so if the State goes bankrupt, Tier 1 retirees may find themselves with no pension.

Defined benefit plans always had this risk, but people weren't aware of it. Defined contribution plans are much more sustainable and, therefore, more likely to be available to the worker at retirement. Your employer can't tap a 401(k). The federal government can ... as they did in Italy and Cyprus to pay down government debt.

Comment: What total nonsense this is, an idea that no doubt springs from her need to appear effective for the upcoming provincial election.  High speed trains have been examined for Canada on several occasions.  They are financially a non-starter due to their need for totally dedicated and totally grade separated tracks;  i.e. no level crossings at all.  If I recall correctly, a high speed train between Toronto and Montreal, for example , would require almost 400 new bridges.  The costs would be staggering - well into the multi billion dollar range.  To be feasible, there needs to be a very large number of  trips  taken on the railway and this requires a travelling population far in excess of  population or rail trip densities in Canada.  Basically she is going to throw away $15,000,000  of taxpayer's money just to start things off and just to make her look good.

Comment: Our corporation pays 35% federal corporate tax, 9% state corporate tax, and 7% workers' compensation. Comment: But all Obamacare did was set certain standards. Health plans must meet basic criteria, eliminating some of the loopholes insurance companies used to deny coverage. Since everyone participates in the health care industry (with 50% of your costs coming as a non-working senior), everyone has to have insurance. And, since the right resists a single payer option, it implemented a modest progressive tax to make healthcare affordable for over 20 million people who didn't have access to is previously. This isn't that different than any of the other programs I mentioned that set the infrastructure we have today. Without these regulations, people like me who were born with a pre-existing condition had absolutely ZERO options for affordable private health care (I never considered a career without a group health plan, and have been lucky to stay employed). The right has hobbled the ACA, and instead of fixing it wants to dismantle its progress, even though it demonstrably made things better.

Comment: From his 1974 book perhaps something every one of our representatives should consider when they believe they know better than I do, with the money I earn. "The root facts here are the incommensurability and incomplete communicability of human wants and values.  George Bernard Shaw long ago observed, “Do not do unto others as you would have them do unto you.  They may have different tastes.”  Social good, as in the determination of a just income distribution, is an abstraction of some kind from the individual values of the members of the society.  But this abstraction can only be based on interpersonally observed behavior, as in market purchases or voting, not on the full range of an individual’s feelings.  As is by now well known, attempts to form social judgments by aggregating individual expressed preferences always lead to the possibility of paradox.

Thus there cannot be a completely consistent meaning to collective rationality."
Thank you Sir

Comment: While Doppelt should be commended, his references to overpopulation are dated. The Population Bomb was published in 1968 and Asimov during the same period.   Fortunately the world took their warnings seriously, utilized birth control,  and  the world's rate of population growth has greatly diminished:
"A picture of the world population in the very long-run shows extremely rapid growth. Indeed, for a long time the world population grew at an increasing rate. However, if we focus on the last couple of decades, we see that this pattern no longer holds, as the annual rate of population growth has been recently going down. 1962 saw the growth rate peak at 2.1%, and it has since fallen to almost half. A long historical period of accelerated growth has thus come to an end."  (https://ourworldindata.org/world-population-growth/)
While poor areas in Africa and the Middle East still have problems,  in much of the West birth rates are falling below death rates.
The real problem now is technology.

Comment: Actually, O'bonobo, you're a little off here.  And I speak as someone who has hunted all his life, but also as a biologist.  Predators, i.e. those which kill for food, don't target the biggest, strongest animals.  The energy required for, say a lion pride to bring down the biggest buffalo in the herd is excessive in terms of the energy the pride would derive from the meat of their kill.  To say nothing of the increased risk of injury or death attacking the biggest bull.  That's why they go after the small, weak ones.  And that's why herds of prey animals keep the small weak ones in the middle surrounded by the big strong ones.  Even the dinosaurs did that.  So your 'big trophy moose' doesn't have much to do with your dietary requirements.  Only those of your ego.  But I understand that probably needs considerable 'stroking', seeing as to how almost no one takes you seriously.  Just wash your hands afterwards.

Comment: I am going to disagree with you. Choosing not to detain the man at that time is not an admission that they were in the wrong. Based on the information available, the man had not done anything of a threatening nature and did not pose an immediate public danger. However, they did ascertain that he was armed. He violated the law when he refused to comply with a lawful order and it is likely that he will be charged for that crime, as well as have his bail revoked. The fact that doing what he did could have gotten him killed is exactly why APD's actions were noteworthy. They apparently chose to deal with the suspect under more controlled conditions with less risk to the officers, as well as the suspect, rather than escalate a non-threatening contact. We don't know enough to determine whether that WAS indeed the best decision, but I find it very encouraging that a police department is using discretion rather than relying on the show-of-force tactics that so often lead to tragedy.

Comment: For those who love a good game-meat sausage or jerky (some of my favorites), there are reports on the internet of how to destroy T. gondii. Much of the misinformation is being spread by cat-lickers who were born to lie. It's not as easy as just freezing the meat for a few days. They have found that even washing your hands and garden-vegetables in bleach and hydrochloric acids and digestive enzymes will not destroy T. gondii oocysts. It's one really tough bugger. It can even survive living in saltwater, this is why so many rare and endangered marine-mammals (all the way up to whales) are now dying-off along all coastlines around the world from contracting T. gondii in run-off from the lands.

For those of you who enjoy game-meat sausage or jerky, you CAN destroy the viable T. gondii parasites and cysts in the meat, but you MUST freeze the meat to temperatures below (MINUS) -20º F. The common home-freezer in a fridge/freezer-combo rarely goes down to below (PLUS) +15 F.

(cont.)

Comment: "I actually wish we would get rid of fertility clinics if it isn't working naturally then find another hobby."

What a terrible and insensitive statement. Wanted to have children and raise them to adulthood is NOT a hobby like model aircraft or trains. I respect women who don't want to have children, to me it is your choice and good for you for making it. On the flip side, many women who can't have or struggle having children, the problem can challenge their womanhood, can make them feel less of a woman.  My wife and I struggled through all this, went to clinics and eventually adopted a wonderful son. The day she found out she could not have children she says was the worst day of her life, it was traumatic for her. Every time our son asks about having a sibling, it just jabs at my wife soul. 

You just lack empathy and it is apparent. You may not want children but for many women wanting to have children in part of their DNA.
